neutron scattering
In 1932, Chadwick and Feather used the apparatus to study the scattering of protons off the polonium target. They found that the protons scattered at an angle of about 6°. This angle is known as the Chadwick angle. The neutron was then detected by a detector placed inside the target. The neutron was found to have a wavelength of about 1.8 Å. This wavelength corresponds to a mass of about 1.002 amu. The neutron thus had a mass of about 1/1800th of the mass of a hydrogen atom. The

neutron scattering
In 1932, Chadwick and Feather used the apparatus to study the scattering of protons off the polonium target. They found that the protons scattered more easily than expected. This suggested that there was an additional particle present, one that could explain the observed effects. Chadwick and Feather then repeated the experiment with neutrons instead of protons. The neutrons scattered much less easily than expected. Chadwick concluded that the neutron must be responsible for the observed effects. He also realized that the neutron must be very light, since it could not be produced by the reaction between protons and electrons. Chad

The earliest known mention of the town dates back to 1245 when it was called Quistan. In 1277, the town was granted a charter by King Edward I of England. The town grew rapidly during the medieval period, becoming a major centre of trade and commerce. The town was heavily damaged during the English Civil War but has recovered well over the centuries. Today, Whiston is a thriving community with a population of approximately 10,000 people.

He was then living in Seville where he died in 1492. His death certificate lists him as "deceased" and states that he was 63 years old at the time of his death. His tombstone reads: "Here lies the body of Sebastian Cabot, knight, of the city of Venice, who departed this life on the 17th day of October, year of our Lord one thousand four hundred and ninety-two." The inscription on the stone reads: "He was a good man, a noble knight, and a great builder."

The proton–neutron model explained the puzzle of dinitrogen. When 14N was proposed to consist of 3 pairs each of protons and neutrons, with an additional unpaired neutron and proton each contributing a spin of 1⁄2 ħ in the same direction for a total spin of 1 ħ, the model became viable. Soon, neutrons were used to naturally explain spin differences in many different nuclides in the same way.

determined to find a solution. In 1930, Chadwick discovered the neutron, which he named the "chad." The neutron was a fundamental particle, not a subatomic particle like the electron or proton. It could be produced in nuclear reactions, and it could interact with other particles. Chadwick also found that the neutron was heavier than the proton, so it would not fit inside the nucleus. This led him to propose that the neutron was a separate entity from the nucleus, and that the nucleus consisted of protons and neutrons. This model was called the "proton-neutron model."
